ground_truth: Mr. Darcy raises a hand to his mouth, then leaps from his seat, with his mouth tight and brows furrowed. Lizzie lowers her eyes, sadness fills her face, and she curtsies. Mr. Darcy gives his usual stilted bow in return, turns, and leaves the room. At the door, he stops and looks back at Lizzie for a moment before finally walking out. Outside, horses are being harnessed to the carriage, and Mrs. Gardiner and Lizzie emerge, dressed in their outdoor clothes. Lizzie turns to him, then climbs into the carriage. At Pemberley, Mr. Darcy is sitting in the drawing room, watching Georgiana practice her piano playing. The Hursts, Mr. Bingley, and Miss Bingley are also present. Miss Bingley stands up, and with a look of utter contempt, Mr. Darcy leaves the room. The two sisters exchange glances. At Longbourn, the Gardiners' four children are playing on the lawn when the carriage pulls into the driveway, and they quickly hurry over to greet it. As the four white horses come to a halt, the footman comes over to open the carriage door and help Lizzie out. Briefly greeting the children, Lizzie hurries inside, where Jane has come to meet her. In her bedroom, Mrs. Bennet is lying back in her chair, fanning herself. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy is traveling in a carriage, his expression thoughtful and determined, with four chestnut horses speed through the countryside, a seated driver and two footmen on the back of Darcy's carriage. Now, the Bennet sisters are taking lunch with the Gardiners. Later, Lizzie enters a room and finds Jane standing at the window, gazing out at the gardens. She shuts the door behind her, then walks over to her sister. Lizzie opens it and begins to read. Lydia and Wickham climb into a carriage in the dead of night. Jane looks away with a serious expression, and Lizzie leaves the room. Now, Lizzie is in her nightgown, standing in front of the mirror in her room. Slowly, she looks herself in the eye, then sits down. Her face is full of sorrow, and her eyes are glistening with as yet unshed tears. She remembers Mr. Darcy striding away from her. A knock disturbs her thoughts. Jane comes in and shuts the door behind her, walks over to Lizzie, and takes her hand. Lizzie looks down, then takes Jane's hand again. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy has arrived at a coaching inn. As the innkeeper leads him, a serving boy comes out with tankards full of ale, and Mr. Darcy takes one and drinks from it. The next day, Kitty is playing with a cup and bowl in the garden when she spies a two-wheeled curricle approaching through the trees, and she quickly scampers off across the lawn.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Mr. Darcy lifts a hand to his lips, then jumps from his chair, with his lips tight and brows knitted. Lizzie drops her eyes, melancholy fills her visage, and she curtsies. Mr. Darcy gives his regular stiff bow in response, pivots, and exits the chamber. At the entrance, he pauses and glances back at Lizzie for a moment before ultimately walking out. Outside, steeds are being harnessed to the coach, and Mrs. Gardiner and Lizzie surface, clothed in their outer garments. Lizzie turns to him, then ascends into the coach. At Pemberley, Mr. Darcy is seated in the parlor, observing Georgiana practice her pianoforte playing. The Hursts, Mr. Bingley, and Miss Bingley are also in attendance. Miss Bingley stands up, and with a glance of complete disdain, Mr. Darcy exits the chamber. The two siblings exchange looks. At Longbourn, the Gardiners' four offspring are playing on the grass when the coach pulls into the driveway, and they quickly rush over to welcome it. As the four ivory horses come to a stop, the attendant comes over to open the coach door and assist Lizzie out. Briefly greeting the offspring, Lizzie rushes inside, where Jane has come to greet her. In her bedroom, Mrs. Bennet is reclining back in her chair, fanning herself. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy is journeying in a coach, his expression pensive and resolute, with four auburn horses speeding through the countryside, a seated driver and two attendants on the rear of Darcy's coach. Now, the Bennet siblings are taking lunch with the Gardiners. Later, Lizzie enters a chamber and finds Jane standing at the window, gazing out at the grounds. She shuts the door behind her, then walks over to her sibling. Lizzie opens it and begins to read. Lydia and Wickham climb into a coach in the dead of night. Jane looks away with a grave expression, and Lizzie exits the chamber. Now, Lizzie is in her nightdress, standing in front of the mirror in her chamber. Slowly, she looks herself in the eye, then sits down. Her visage is full of grief, and her eyes are shining with as yet unshed tears. She recalls Mr. Darcy striding away from her. A rap interrupts her thoughts. Jane enters and shuts the door behind her, walks over to Lizzie, and takes her hand. Lizzie looks down, then takes Jane's hand again. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy has arrived at a coaching inn. As the innkeeper leads him, a serving lad comes out with tankards full of ale, and Mr. Darcy takes one and sips from it. The next day, Kitty is playing with a cup and bowl in the grounds when she spies a two-wheeled curricle approaching through the trees, and she quickly scurries off across the grass.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Mr. Darcy raises his hand to his mouth, leaps up with a tight-lipped, furrowed brow. Lizzie lowers her eyes, sadness on her face, and curtsies. Mr. Darcy bows stiffly, turns, and leaves the room. At the door, he pauses to glance back at Lizzie before exiting. Outside, horses are being harnessed to the carriage as Mrs. Gardiner and Lizzie, in outdoor attire, appear. Lizzie turns to him, then climbs into the carriage. At Pemberley, Mr. Darcy watches Georgiana practice piano in the drawing room, joined by the Hursts, Mr. Bingley, and Miss Bingley. With a contemptuous look from Miss Bingley, Darcy leaves the room, exchanging glances with her sister. At Longbourn, the Gardiners' children play on the lawn until the carriage arrives, and they rush to greet it. As the white horses halt, the footman opens the carriage door and helps Lizzie out. Briefly greeting the children, Lizzie hurries inside to meet Jane. In her bedroom, Mrs. Bennet lounges, fanning herself. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy travels in a carriage, thoughtful and determined, with chestnut horses racing through the countryside, a driver and two footmen aboard. Now, the Bennet sisters lunch with the Gardiners. Later, Lizzie finds Jane at a window, gazing at the garden. She shuts the door, walks over, and opens a letter to read. Lydia and Wickham climb into a carriage at night. Jane looks away seriously, and Lizzie exits. Lizzie, in her nightgown, stands before her mirror, sorrowful, her eyes glistening with unshed tears, recalling Mr. Darcy leaving. A knock interrupts her thoughts. Jane enters, shuts the door, approaches Lizzie, and takes her hand. Lizzie looks down and takes Jane's hand again. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy arrives at a coaching inn. Led by the innkeeper, a serving boy offers him ale, and Darcy drinks. The next day, Kitty plays in the garden and spots a two-wheeled curricle approaching, prompting her to scamper across the lawn.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Mr. Darcy raises a hand to his mouth, then leaps up, his mouth tight and brows furrowed. Lizzie lowers her eyes, sadness filling her face, and curtsies. Mr. Darcy gives a stiff bow, turns, and leaves. At the door, he pauses, looks back at Lizzie, then exits. Outside, horses are harnessed; Mrs. Gardiner and Lizzie appear in outdoor clothes. Lizzie turns to him, then boards the carriage. At Pemberley, Mr. Darcy watches Georgiana at the piano. The Hursts, Mr. Bingley, and Miss Bingley are there. Miss Bingley rises, and Mr. Darcy leaves with contempt. The sisters exchange looks. At Longbourn, the Gardiners' children play on the lawn, greeting the carriage. As horses halt, the footman helps Lizzie out. Briefly greeting them, Lizzie hurries inside, met by Jane. In her room, Mrs. Bennet fans herself. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy travels in a carriage, thoughtful, determined, with chestnut horses and footmen. The Bennet sisters lunch with the Gardiners. Later, Lizzie finds Jane at the window. Lizzie opens a letter. Lydia and Wickham enter a carriage at night. Jane looks serious, and Lizzie leaves. Lizzie, in her nightgown, stands before the mirror, face sorrowful, eyes glistening. She recalls Mr. Darcy walking away. A knock interrupts her. Jane enters, takes Lizzie's hand. Lizzie looks down, takes Jane's hand again. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy arrives at an inn, takes an ale from a serving boy. The next day, Kitty sees a curricle approaching and scampers off.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Mr. Darcy raises a hand thoughtfully to his mouth, then suddenly, with a burst of energy, he leaps up from his seat. His mouth is tightly pressed together, and his brows are drawn in a deep furrow of concern. Lizzie lowers her eyes, her face suffused with a profound sadness, and she performs a graceful curtsy. In response, Mr. Darcy executes his typical, somewhat awkward stilted bow, turns promptly, and exits the room. As he reaches the door, he pauses for a brief moment and glances back at Lizzie one last time before he finally steps out. 

Outside, there is a bustling scene where horses are diligently being harnessed to the carriage, and Mrs. Gardiner and Lizzie step out, wearing their appropriate outdoor attire. Lizzie turns to him with a fleeting look, then climbs into the waiting carriage. At Pemberley, Mr. Darcy is comfortably seated in the drawing room, observing with a sense of pride as Georgiana practices her piano playing. Joining him in the room are the Hursts, Mr. Bingley, and Miss Bingley. With an expression of utter contempt, Miss Bingley stands up, prompting Mr. Darcy to leave the room. The two sisters exchange knowing glances as he departs.

At Longbourn, the Gardiners' four lively children are joyfully playing on the sunlit lawn when the carriage arrives, pulling into the driveway. The children eagerly hurry over to greet it. As the set of four elegant white horses comes to a graceful halt, the footman steps forward to open the carriage door and assist Lizzie in alighting. Lizzie briefly acknowledges the children's enthusiastic greetings before she hurries inside, where Jane waits to warmly meet her. Meanwhile, in her bedroom, Mrs. Bennet reclines in her chair, fanning herself leisurely. 

Elsewhere, Mr. Darcy is on a journey in his carriage, his expression both thoughtful and determined, as the four powerful chestnut horses speed across the countryside. A seated driver skillfully handles the reins, while two attentive footmen occupy the back of the carriage. Back at the Bennet household, the sisters are comfortably taking lunch with the Gardiners. Later on, Lizzie enters a room only to find Jane standing quietly by the window, gazing out contemplatively at the gardens. She shuts the door behind her, then approaches her sister. Lizzie opens it and commences reading it aloud. 

In the dead of night, Lydia and Wickham climb into a carriage under the veil of darkness. Jane averts her gaze with a serious expression, and Lizzie leaves the room quietly. Now, Lizzie stands in her nightgown in front of her room mirror. Slowly, she meets her own eyes in the reflection, then sits down, her face a mask of sorrow and her eyes shimmering with unshed tears. She recalls the moment Mr. Darcy strode away from her. A knock gently interrupts her thoughts. Jane enters and closes the door softly behind her, walking over to Lizzie's side and taking her hand in a comforting gesture. Lizzie looks downward before taking Jane's hand again with a sense of solace.

Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy has reached a coaching inn. As the innkeeper guides him, a serving boy emerges carrying tankards full of ale, and Mr. Darcy takes one, drinking from it thoughtfully. The next day, Kitty is amusing herself with a cup and bowl in the garden when she notices a two-wheeled curricle emerging through the trees. Eager to see what is happening, she quickly scampers across the lawn.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Mr. Darcy raises his hand in a thoughtful manner to his mouth, contemplating deeply, and then quite suddenly, with an unexpected burst of energy, he leaps up from his seated position. His lips are tightly pressed together, a clear indication of his inner turmoil, and his brows are furrowed into a deep line of concern. Meanwhile, Lizzie lowers her eyes, her expression filled with profound sadness, and she performs a graceful, respectful curtsy. In response to her gesture, Mr. Darcy executes his typical bow, which is somewhat awkward and stilted, then promptly turns and exits the room. As he reaches the door, he pauses for just a brief moment, casting one more glance back at Lizzie before he finally steps out into the corridor beyond.

Outside, there is a lively and bustling scene unfolding where horses are being diligently harnessed to the carriage in preparation for departure. Mrs. Gardiner and Lizzie step out into the open air, attired in their appropriate outdoor clothing. Lizzie turns her gaze toward Mr. Darcy with a fleeting look before she climbs into the waiting carriage. At Pemberley, Mr. Darcy finds comfort as he sits in the drawing room, observing with a sense of pride and satisfaction as Georgiana practices her piano playing with dedication. Also present in the room are the Hursts, Mr. Bingley, and Miss Bingley. With an expression of utter contempt, Miss Bingley stands abruptly, prompting Mr. Darcy to leave the room. The two sisters share and exchange knowing glances as he departs.

At Longbourn, the Gardiners' four lively children are playing joyfully on the sunlit lawn when the carriage pulls into the driveway. The children eagerly hurry over to greet its arrival. As the set of four elegant white horses comes to a graceful halt, the attentive footman steps forward to open the carriage door and assist Lizzie in alighting. Lizzie briefly acknowledges the children's enthusiastic greetings with a smile before she hurries inside the house, where Jane is waiting to warmly meet her. Meanwhile, in the comfort of her bedroom, Mrs. Bennet reclines leisurely in her chair, fanning herself with a sense of contentment.

Elsewhere, Mr. Darcy is embarked on a journey in his carriage, his expression both thoughtful and determined, as the four powerful chestnut horses speed across the picturesque countryside. The seated driver skillfully handles the reins, while two attentive footmen occupy the back of the carriage, ensuring everything is in order. Back at the Bennet household, the sisters are comfortably enjoying lunch with the Gardiners. Later on, Lizzie enters a room only to find Jane standing quietly by the window, gazing out contemplatively at the gardens spread before her. She shuts the door gently behind her, then approaches her sister with quiet resolve. Lizzie opens the letter and begins reading it aloud.

In the dead of night, under the protective veil of darkness, Lydia and Wickham furtively climb into a waiting carriage. Jane averts her gaze with a serious, concerned expression, and Lizzie leaves the room quietly, lost in thought. Now, Lizzie stands in her nightgown in front of her room mirror. Slowly, she meets her own eyes in the reflection, then sits down, her face a mask of sorrow and her eyes shimmering with unshed tears. She recalls, with a heavy heart, the moment Mr. Darcy strode away from her. A gentle knock on the door softly interrupts her thoughts. Jane enters quietly and closes the door behind her, walking over to Lizzie’s side and taking her hand in a comforting gesture. Lizzie looks downward for a moment before taking Jane’s hand again, finding a sense of solace in her sister’s presence.

Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy has reached a coaching inn. As the attentive innkeeper guides him to a suitable place, a serving boy emerges carrying tankards generously filled with ale, and Mr. Darcy takes one, drinking from it thoughtfully. The next morning, Kitty is amusing herself with a cup and bowl in the garden when she notices a two-wheeled curricle making its way through the trees. Eager to see what is happening, she quickly scampers across the sun-drenched lawn, her curiosity piqued.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Mr. Darcy slowly raises his hand to his mouth, the slight movement conveying his deep contemplation, before he abruptly leaps from his seat, his mouth forming a tight line and his brows drawn together in a furrow of concern. As he does so, Lizzie allows her eyes to fall, her gaze dropping to the floor, as a wave of sadness washes over her features, and she performs a graceful curtsy. In response, Mr. Darcy manages to return her gesture with his characteristic stilted bow, before turning on his heel and decisively exiting the room. Upon reaching the door, he pauses momentarily, casting a lingering glance back at Lizzie as if imprinting the moment in his memory, before resolutely walking out. Outside the room, the clamor of horses being harnessed to the carriage fills the air, and moments later, Mrs. Gardiner and Lizzie emerge, wrapped in their outdoor attire with the fabric rustling gently. Lizzie turns her attention towards Mr. Darcy, sparing him a final look before she climbs into the waiting carriage. Meanwhile, at Pemberley, Mr. Darcy finds himself settled in the drawing room, his gaze intently following Georgiana as she practices her piano playing, the melodies filling the space around them. Nearby, the Hursts, Mr. Bingley, and Miss Bingley are present, quietly absorbed in the scene. Disruption comes as Miss Bingley rises to her feet with an expression of utter contempt, prompting Mr. Darcy to stand and immediately exit the room. The two sisters, marked by the exchange, glance at one another. At Longbourn, the Gardiner children are a flurry of excitement, playing energetically on the lawn when the carriage pulls into the driveway. Recognizing the arrival, they hasten over in delight as the four white horses come to a standstill. The footman moves with practiced precision to open the carriage door, extending his hand to assist Lizzie as she steps down. Briefly acknowledging the children's enthusiasm with a greeting, Lizzie quickly makes her way inside, where Jane stands ready to welcome her. Upstairs, in her bedroom, Mrs. Bennet reclines in her chair, intermittently fanning herself with deliberate, repetitive motions. Elsewhere, Mr. Darcy is on a journey, seated in a carriage with a contemplative yet determined expression etched across his face, as four chestnut horses gallop with purpose through the countryside, a driver skillfully at the reins and two footmen positioned at the back. Meanwhile, the Bennet sisters share a midday meal with the Gardiners, their gathering marked by familiar camaraderie. Later, Lizzie quietly enters a room to find Jane standing lost in thought at the window, her eyes fixed on the gardens beyond. She softly closes the door behind her and approaches her sister with purpose. Lizzie retrieves a letter, unfurling it to begin reading. Under the cover of darkness, Lydia and Wickham slip into a waiting carriage, the night's stillness enveloping them. Jane, her face clouded with seriousness, averts her gaze, prompting Lizzie to quietly take her leave from the room. At night, Lizzie, dressed in her nightgown, stands contemplatively in front of the mirror in her room, her eyes meeting her own reflection with a sense of deep introspection. She eventually lowers herself onto a nearby seat, her face a canvas of sorrow, her eyes glistening with unshed tears as echoes of Mr. Darcy's departure play on her mind. A soft knock on her door breaks her reverie, and Jane enters, closing the door with a soft click before crossing the room to reach Lizzie's side. Jane reaches out to take Lizzie's hand, prompting Lizzie to cast her eyes down before grasping Jane's hand in return. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy arrives at a bustling coaching inn, where he is promptly guided by the innkeeper. A serving boy emerges, balancing tankards brimming with ale, one of which Mr. Darcy accepts, taking a hearty drink. The following day, Kitty is in the garden, entertaining herself with a cup and bowl when she catches sight of a two-wheeled curricle making its way through the trees. Sensing intrigue, she quickly scampers off across the lawn to investigate.

test_cases.description: Mr. Darcy raises a hand to his mouth, then leaps from his seat with a tight-lipped expression and furrowed brows. Lizzie lowers her eyes sadly and curtsies. He bows stiffly in return, turns, and pauses at the door to look back at her before leaving the room. Outside, while horses are being harnessed to the carriage, Mrs. Gardiner and Lizzie appear in outdoor attire. Lizzie turns to Mr. Darcy, then climbs into the carriage. At Pemberley, Mr. Darcy watches Georgiana practice piano in the drawing room with the Hursts, Mr. Bingley, and Miss Bingley present. Miss Bingley stands up disdainfully, prompting Mr. Darcy to leave. The two sisters exchange glances. At Longbourn, the Gardiners' four children rush to greet the arriving carriage. As the horses halt, the footman opens the door and helps Lizzie out. After a brief greeting, Lizzie hurries inside to meet Jane. Mrs. Bennet is in her bedroom, fanning herself. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy travels determinedly in a carriage, passing through countryside with a driver and footmen. At the Bennet residence, the sisters have lunch with the Gardiners. Later, Lizzie finds Jane at the window and approaches her. Lizzie opens a letter and starts reading. Lydia and Wickham board a carriage at night. Jane looks serious, and Lizzie exits the room. Alone in her room, Lizzie stands sorrowfully in front of the mirror, her eyes glistening with unshed tears as she recalls Mr. Darcy walking away. A knock interrupts her reflection; Jane enters, approaches Lizzie, and they hold hands. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy arrives at a coaching inn, takes a tankard of ale from a serving boy, and drinks. The following day, Kitty plays in the garden and spots a curricle approaching, prompting her to scamper across the lawn.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Mr. Darcy, a wealthy gentleman known for his reserved demeanor and significant social standing, raises a hand to his mouth, then leaps from his seat, with his mouth tight and brows furrowed. Lizzie, short for Elizabeth Bennet and known for her wit and independent spirit, lowers her eyes, sadness fills her face, and she curtsies. Mr. Darcy gives his usual stilted bow, a formality rooted in his upbringing among the English upper class, in return, turns, and leaves the room. At the door, he stops and looks back at Lizzie for a moment before finally walking out. Outside, horses are being harnessed to the carriage, a typical mode of transport for the gentry in the Regency era, and Mrs. Gardiner and Lizzie emerge, dressed in their outdoor clothes suitable for travel. Lizzie turns to him, then climbs into the carriage. At Pemberley, Darcy's large and impressive estate in Derbyshire, Mr. Darcy is sitting in the drawing room, a common space for entertaining guests, watching Georgiana, his younger sister who is known for her musical talent, practice her piano playing. The Hursts, Mr. Bingley, a close friend of Darcy, and Miss Bingley, who harbors feelings for Darcy, are also present. Miss Bingley stands up, and with a look of utter contempt because of her unrequited affection, Mr. Darcy leaves the room. The two sisters exchange glances. At Longbourn, the modest estate of the Bennet family located in Hertfordshire, the Gardiners' four children are playing on the lawn when the carriage pulls into the driveway, and they quickly hurry over to greet it. As the four white horses come to a halt, the footman comes over to open the carriage door and help Lizzie out, following the protocol of the period. Briefly greeting the children, Lizzie hurries inside, where Jane, her kind and gentle older sister, has come to meet her. In her bedroom, Mrs. Bennet is lying back in her chair, fanning herself, overwhelmed by the prospect of marrying off her daughters. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy is traveling in a carriage, his expression thoughtful and determined, with four chestnut horses speed through the picturesque countryside, a seated driver and two footmen on the back of Darcy's carriage. Now, the Bennet sisters are taking lunch with the Gardiners, their relatives who live in London. Later, Lizzie enters a room and finds Jane standing at the window, gazing out at the gardens of Longbourn. She shuts the door behind her, then walks over to her sister. Lizzie opens it and begins to read, likely a letter. Lydia and Wickham, whose scandalous elopement caused a family crisis, climb into a carriage in the dead of night. Jane looks away with a serious expression, and Lizzie leaves the room. Now, Lizzie is in her nightgown, standing in front of the mirror in her room. Slowly, she looks herself in the eye, then sits down. Her face is full of sorrow, and her eyes are glistening with as yet unshed tears. She remembers Mr. Darcy striding away from her. A knock disturbs her thoughts. Jane comes in and shuts the door behind her, walks over to Lizzie, and takes her hand as a gesture of sisterly support. Lizzie looks down, then takes Jane's hand again. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy has arrived at a coaching inn, a common stopover for long journeys. As the innkeeper leads him, a serving boy comes out with tankards full of ale, a popular beverage of the time, and Mr. Darcy takes one and drinks from it. The next day, Kitty, one of the younger Bennet sisters, is playing with a cup and bowl in the garden when she spies a two-wheeled curricle, a light, open carriage drawn by horses, approaching through the trees, and she quickly scampers off across the lawn.

test_cases.name: Addition (~50%)
test_cases.description: Mr Darcy raises a hand to his mouth then leaps from his seat with his mouth tight and brows furrowed. Lizzie lowers her eyes. sadness fills her face and she curtsies. Mr Darcy gives his usual stilted bow in return turns and leaves the room. At the door he stops and looks back at Lizzie for a moment before finally walking out. Outside horses are being harnessed to the carriage and Mrs Gardiner and Lizzie emerge dressed in their outdoor clothes. Lizzie turns to him then climbs into the carriage. At Pemberley Mr Darcy is sitting in the drawing room watching Georgiana practice her piano playing. The Hursts. Mr Bingley and Miss Bingley are also present. Miss Bingley stands up and with a look of utter contempt Mr Darcy leaves the room. The two sisters exchange glances. At Longbourn the Gardiners' four children are playing on the lawn when the carriage pulls into the driveway and they quickly hurry over to greet it. As the four white horses come to a halt the footman comes over to open the carriage door and help Lizzie out. Briefly greeting the children. Lizzie hurries inside where Jane has come to meet her. In her bedroom Mrs Bennet is lying back in her chair fanning herself. Meanwhile Mr Darcy is traveling in a carriage his expression thoughtful and determined with four chestnut horses speed through the countryside. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. a seated driver and two footmen on the back of Darcy's carriage. Now the Bennet sisters are taking lunch with the Gardiners. Later Lizzie enters a room and finds Jane standing at the window gazing out at the gardens. She shuts the door behind her then walks over to her sister. Lizzie opens it and begins to read. Lydia and Wickham climb into a carriage in the dead of night. Jane looks away with a serious expression and Lizzie leaves the room. Now Lizzie is in her nightgown standing in front of the mirror in her room. Slowly she looks herself in the eye then sits down. Her face is full of sorrow and her eyes are glistening with as yet unshed tears. She remembers Mr Darcy striding away from her. A knock disturbs her thoughts. Jane comes in and shuts the door behind her. walks over to Lizzie and takes her hand. Lizzie looks down then takes Jane's hand again. Meanwhile Mr Darcy has arrived at a coaching inn. As the innkeeper leads him a serving boy comes out with tankards full of ale and Mr Darcy takes one and drinks from it. The next day Kitty is playing with a cup and bowl in the garden when she spies a twowheeled curricle approaching through the trees and she quickly scampers off across the lawn.

test_cases.name: Addition (~80%)
test_cases.description: Mr Darcy raises a hand to his mouth then leaps from his seat with his mouth tight and brows furrowed. Lizzie lowers her eyes. sadness fills her face and she curtsies. Mr Darcy gives his usual stilted bow in return turns and leaves the room. At the door he stops and looks back at Lizzie for a moment before finally walking out. Outside horses are being harnessed to the carriage and Mrs Gardiner and Lizzie emerge dressed in their outdoor clothes. Lizzie turns to him then climbs into the carriage. At Pemberley Mr Darcy is sitting in the drawing room watching Georgiana practice her piano playing. The Hursts. Mr Bingley and Miss Bingley are also present. Miss Bingley stands up and with a look of utter contempt Mr Darcy leaves the room. The two sisters exchange glances. At Longbourn the Gardiners' four children are playing on the lawn when the carriage pulls into the driveway and they quickly hurry over to greet it. As the four white horses come to a halt the footman comes over to open the carriage door and help Lizzie out. Briefly greeting the children. Lizzie hurries inside where Jane has come to meet her. In her bedroom Mrs Bennet is lying back in her chair fanning herself. Meanwhile Mr Darcy is traveling in a carriage his expression thoughtful and determined with four chestnut horses speed through the countryside. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. his calculated every move a daring escape from the everwatchful royal guards. test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Professor Wingtip scratches a feather to his beak, then vaults from his branch, with his beak curled and talons clenched. Samantha raises her antennae, joy fills her jaw, and she somersaults. Professor Wingtip offers his traditional robotic salute in reply, pivots, and exits the cave. At the portal, he halts and glances back at Samantha for a moment before eventually flying out. Outside, donkeys are being tethered to the wagon, and Lady Swallowtail and Samantha appear, cloaked in their underwater outfits. Samantha nods at him, then crawls into the wagon. At Rainyvale, Professor Wingtip is lounging in the gallery, observing Ferdinand paint his egg portrait. The Dabbleducks, Sir Swizzle, and Lady Swizzle are likewise present. Lady Swizzle rises, and with a look of utter fascination, Professor Wingtip evacuates the gallery. The five brothers swap smirks. At Sunhill, the Swallowtails’ three piglets are tumbling on the court when the wagon rolls up the boulevard, and they rapidly bounce over to greet it. As the six grey donkeys skid to a pause, the butler trots over to pry the wagon lid and assist Samantha out. Briefly saluting the piglets, Samantha zips inside, where Paula has come to hug her. In her cottage, Madam Dragonfly is reclining in her raft, misting herself. Meanwhile, Professor Wingtip is gliding in a zeppelin, his visage pensive and resolute, with three raven bats darting through the desert, a perched navigator and one maid on the roof of Wingtip’s zeppelin. Now, the Dragonfly siblings are sharing pastries with the Swallows. Later, Samantha drifts into a hollow and finds Paula perched at the porthole, peering out at the shoals. She seals the hatch after her, then scuttles over to her sibling. Samantha unlatches it and begins to hum. Ethel and Victor scramble into a zeppelin in the light of dawn. Paula gazes elsewhere with a cheerful countenance, and Samantha evaporates from the hollow. Now, Samantha is in her toga, standing before the reflective pool in her hollow. Gradually, she regards her own reflection, then collapses. Her visage is brimming with elation, and her gaze is shimmering with as yet unspilled giggles. She recalls Professor Wingtip frolicking away from her. A gong interrupts her reveries. Paula enters and closes the curtain behind her, strolls over to Samantha, and grips her claw. Samantha glances up, then squeezes Paula’s claw anew. Meanwhile, Professor Wingtip has landed at a lounging quayside. As the barista guides him, a busboy emerges with chalices brimming with nectar, and Professor Wingtip seizes one and sips from it. The subsequent dawn, Ellie is juggling with a hoop and crate in the orchard when she spots a six-legged cart trundling through the brambles, and she swiftly dashes off across the glade.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Mr. Darcy, visibly tense, leaves the room after exchanging a brief farewell with Lizzie. Outside, Lizzie joins Mrs. Gardiner in a carriage. Meanwhile, at Pemberley, Mr. Darcy observes Georgiana's piano practice but exits when Miss Bingley shows disdain. At Longbourn, the Gardiners' children greet the returning Lizzie, who hurriedly seeks Jane. Elsewhere, Mr. Darcy travels purposefully in a carriage with chestnut horses. The Bennet sisters dine with the Gardiners before Lizzie finds Jane, deep in thought, and reads a letter. At night, Lizzie reflects sorrowfully in her room, recalling Mr. Darcy's departure, until Jane comforts her. Meanwhile, Mr. Darcy arrives at an inn, partaking in ale. The following day, Kitty notices a curricle approaching, prompting her to run off.
